title: Do you think most homeless people deserve to be homeless? - Quora

response.answer_text: Who are these people who “deserve” to be homeless? In the United States there are 2.5 million children who are homeless. I have been a high school teacher for nearly 30 years and during that time I have had numerous students who were homeless, struggling to keep up with their studies while living out of a car or spending nights in a homeless shelter. I have volunteered at homeless shelters, where many, if not most, of the people I encountered were families. On any given night 1/3 of people experiencing homelessness are families with children. Of the 36 most developed nations in the world, the United States has the highest rate of childhood poverty, with 1/4 of our young people living in poverty. Do these children “deserve” to be homeless?  Image  Image Domestic violence also contributes to homelessness. Sixteen percent of the overall homeless population reported experiencing domestic violence. Research from a study in New York City indicates that one in five families experienced domestic violence in the five years before entering shelter. Among families that reported domestic violence in the prior five years, 88% reported that it contributed to their homelessness. Half of homeless women say domestic violence was an immediate cause of their homelessness. Do battered women “deserve” to be homeless?  Image Many other homeless people are those suffering from mental illness, unable to get treatment. Thirty-nine percent of homeless people have some form of mental health problem. Do the mentally ill “deserve” to be homeless?  Image There are about 60,000 homeless veterans in the United States, making up 12% of the homeless population. Many suffer from post traumatic stress disorder, disabilities, or substance abuse. Many of these veterans risked life and limb for America. Do these former warriors “deserve” to be homeless?  Image  Image According to figures from 2017, more than one in every eight Americans is living in poverty (40 million people). And almost half of those are living in deep poverty, with reported family income below one-half of the poverty threshold. Are we really to assume that 1/8th of the American population is simply lazy? Many poor people in America are “working poor.” Of the nearly 9 million families in America below the poverty line, approximately 60% have at least one family member who is employed. The U.S. has a much higher rate of working poor than other developed countries.  Graph Do people who go to work everyday, yet still live in poverty, “deserve” to be homeless? The main cause of bankruptcy in America is due to a major illness or astronomical medical expenses. A catastrophic illness, especially involving a family’s primary breadwinner, can wipe out a lifetime of savings and even put that family on the street. Do those who experience catastrophic illness “deserve” to be homeless? There are many reasons for homelessness. Almost none of them involve laziness, a lack of ambition, or a desire to cheat taxpayers in order to live the easy life. Homelessness is not a punishment most people “deserve” for some character failing.  Graph It is certainly easier to dismiss the poor as people who live in poverty because of their own moral defects. Otherwise we have to ask ourselves difficult questions about fundamental problems in our economic system, as well as our own personal responsibility for addressing greater societal issues. It is much more comforting to just think of these people - many of whom are battered women, veterans, the mentally ill, or children - simply as bums who deserve their fate. The uncomfortable alternative is to wonder, “there, but for the grace of God…”  Image UPDATE: Los Angeles County reports that their homeless population increased by 12% this year, with Los Angeles proper seeing a 16% increase. Overall 59,000 people are sleeping on L.A.’s sidewalks. So, ask yourself, does 16% of the population of L.A. suddenly “deserve” homelessness? Or, is it more likely that wage stagnation, combined with a shortage of affordable housing, is causing the rise in homelessness? According to Los Angeles Mayor Eric Garcetti, “Skyrocketing rents statewide and federal disinvestment in affordable housing, combined with an epidemic of untreated trauma and mental illness, is pushing people into homelessness faster than they can be lifted out,” Los Angeles homelessness rises sharply as housing crisis deepens

It's this kind of thinking in our culture that prevents us from supporting programs and policies that ensure all humans get treated as just that… human. So many times, I see that the issue of whether or not a person is “to blame” for their situation affects whether others think it's right or wrong to allow or provide a service. Americans will generally support the idea of giving housing, food, and medical support to a person who can't hold a job because they are blind, but not someone who can’t hold a job because they do drugs. Some say overweight people should be forced to buy a second seat on airplanes because they view obesity as a choice and a lack of self control. Others argue obesity can be a medical condition beyond the victim's control, therefore the seat should be free. There are even some who would allow a woman to get an abortion if she were raped… but not if she were a slut. (Horrifying way to phrase it, I know, but this is literally the mindset. ) So you really need to ask: are all human beings entitled to certain basics, such as food, housing, accomodations for disability, and abortion (or, conversely, should the life of the baby be protected regardless of its mother's guilt or innocence in its conception?) Or can we say, “Well YOU don't get it because it's your fault you’re in this situation”? Let's look at that list again. Food. Shelter. Disability accommodation. Right to control over your own body. Or the baby's right to life. And we're going to grant or deny that based on how deserving the person is? Your question brings to mind a solution to homelessness and unemployment a couple centuries ago in England. There were these things called workhouses. People who could not work/afford a home, be it through disability, financial ruin due to poor choices, or general lack of employment opportunities, could check into a workhouse. They received food and shelter, but they were not given real work. There was not significant real work for them to do. But they could not simply be allowed to NOT work. Oh, no. Just to make the population feel like poor people weren't getting handouts for free, they were given menial tasks, like picking nits, to keep occupied all day. Let's compare this to Finland's solution. Finland is currently distinguished by having virtually no homelessness, while other EU nations are struggling with record highs. How do they do it? By giving all the homeless homes, with NO qualifications for who does and does not deserve one. This means that the very same day a person becomes homeless, they can go to the office and immediately be placed into a flat… not a group shelter or dorm but a cheap yet acceptable personal apartment. This is a permanent home. There are no emergency shelters or waiting periods. Nobody is questioned on why they are homeless. They are simply given a home immediately and without question, because to Finnish people it is unacceptable for any human being to be without a home. And it works great. Many of these people thrive once stable living conditions are provided. People who have not worked in years find steady employment, people struggling with addiction are able to more reliably attend rehabilitation services, and people who could have been ruined by a few months of homelessness during difficult times are able to keep their lives on track. Sure, some Fins are probably kicking back in their free flats and playing video games all day, but nobody else minds. The overall effect on society has been an improvement, with less crime, less unemployment, and less cost overall for human services. (Yes, building homes and paying utilities for homless people results in lower government costs overall than the costs incurred when homeless people are handled the traditional way. For example, an individual living in a home visits the hospital less than if they were living on the streets.) So what do you think? Maybe we can try an approach that's grounded in compassion and respect for all human life? Or do we have to lie awake at night grinding our teeth over the fact we're working a hard job for our home and some lazy bum out there is living for free? Would we really ask ourselves what people “deserve” if the permeating message throughout society were that all of us, every single one of us, by virtue of membership in the siblinghood of the human race, is deserving of dignity, security, and compassion? What if all we could think about was how to lift each other up instead how to tear each other down?

Wow, that's a hot-potato! But yes, I do believe some homeless people deserve to be homeless, but only in the sense that we are all responsible for the decisions we make, whether stupid or out of fear or ignorance. Choices have consequences. It might not seem fair, but it's how life works. If I choose to buy drugs and alcohol with my money and not pay rent, do I "deserve" to be homeless because I'm a bad person? No. I would be homeless because of bad decisions. "Deserve" is a word that speaks to a person's character and smacks of a statement or judgment about a person, not about their actions.  Some homeless people are forced to make choices - like, do I want to buy my medication, the stuff that keeps me alive every day, or do I want to pay rent? Most choose life on the streets rather than no life at all. Do they deserve to be homeless? No. Did they make a bad decision? No. They made the best decision they could. When you start asking if people deserve something, you set yourself up as judge and jury. Unless you know a person's story and the reason they're homeless you can't really know what happened, and therefore you can't really judge them fairly. Many of the alcoholics who are homeless became homeless after losing a loved one, a child, a spouse. They turned to alcohol to self-medicate their pain. They didn't/don't deserve to be homeless. They encountered unbearable grief and did the best they could with the resources and information they had. They don't deserve it, but as a result of choice and consequences they have what they have. Being "deserving" is about punishment and reward. I'm not comfortable saying anyone deserves to be homeless. I am all about pointing out to the homeless that bad decisions got them where they are, and good decisions can get them out. We all have varying degrees of the ability to make different decisions to change our lives. I believe empowering the homeless with the decision making skills they need to change is more effective than deciding if they deserve what they've got or not.

The Homeless? A few thoughts and a couple of experiences I’d like to share. I graduated from the Los Angeles Police Academy in May of 1977. My first division of assignment was Central Division and my first job, there, was walking a foot beat on Skid Row. It was the area east of Spring Street toward the L.A. River, and south of 3rd Street to around 7th Street. This was a time before the word, homeless was used to describe the people living there. Transients was the operative term for the many men and few women who lived there. Alcohol, drugs, mental illness, and often times, the combination of all three were the primary reasons for people being there. Sprinkled among the shivering denizens of the area were a few predators. The ones whose drinking or drugging habits were either fairly manageable, or non-existent. They knew there was money to make from desperate alcoholics and addicts, and flesh to plunder of the almost comatose women…and men…who could not fight off sexual advances. There were, back then and as there still are, church-based missions. Organizations who could feed, shower, and sometimes offer a cot and blanket to the men who lived on the street. There was one which only assisted women. Still another which could take in children with women, located elsewhere. But there were times I’d ask a guy on the street, “Did you try the Mission?” Only to have him reply, “No, they have too many rules, I’d rather be out here.” That conversation would happen more often than the offer to be taken to a mission was accepted. In any conversation about the homeless mentally ill, inevitably, the name Ronald Reagan is brought to the table by today’s (so-called) progressives, blaming his presidential actions on the tsunami of mentally ill people who suddenly found themselves on the street. Having lived in California my first 50 years, I can tell you it was wielding his pen as California’s governor which set them loose. Those same, Reagan-haters always seem to forget that it was the California Legislature, being urged on by those who (supposedly) advocated on behalf of the mentally ill, compelled Reagan to set free the ones who were, “not a danger to themselves or others and not gravely disabled”. Most mentally ill people fall well below that line, yet they are unable to navigate the paths usually followed by the mainstream populace. SIDE NOTE: I wonder how it is that people call the police to deal with the homeless and/or mentally ill and seem to expect a miraculous outcome of some sort. The cops get called and we’re supposed to have a shower, a warm bed and a hot meal within 30 minutes of contact, along with employment and secure storage for all their earthly possessions? This person’s issues have gone on for months, years, perhaps decades and in 15 minutes the cops are supposed to solve what parents, teachers, doctors, nurses, and mental health workers have been unable to prevent or fix prior to the call to 9-1-1. I always want to know, what the CALLER did, prior to calling. You’re angry at the cops because they “did nothing” or “did the wrong thing”. What did you do? What services did you refer the person to? Did you even ask them their name and get their back story? You’re so compassionate – what did you do before you made the decision to call the police? As my career went on, as the general population of the city went upward, so did the amount of street people who seemed to be finding Los Angeles to their liking. Greyhound Therapy, created by both social service and law enforcement agencies in other parts of the country, found that buying a one-way ticket to Los Angeles for problem people seemed to be a pretty good deal. “Winters here are so cold and snowy, James. Wouldn’t you like to see Los Angeles, Venice beach or maybe Hollywood, where it’s sunny all year?” Soon, more individuals and families were on the streets, now joined by immigrants (legal and otherwise). In the 90’s the homeless of Los Angeles were as diverse as the general population itself, with many languages and cultures represented. Some quick anecdotal experiences: Hiroshi was an exchange student who failed to adjust to college on the east coast, deteriorated in mental health and ended up on the streets of L.A. After learning his back story I was able to return him home to his family, in Japan. He had been gone seven years, and they had not heard from him in four. They thought he was dead. I learned his father broke down and wept upon seeing his son return home. Hiroshi’s treatment seemed to help his condition, diagnosed as autism spectrum, after a few weeks home. Richard was in a wheelchair, on Western south of Santa Monica. Someone told me he’d been on the street for weeks. As I approached him he began to roll away, as if in fear. I told him I wanted to help him. He said that most the time the cops just told him to ‘move on’. He got off the bus at the wrong stop and then lost his bus pass. He was an unreported missing person. I got the contact info for the assisted living home he stayed at. Two quick phone calls later, Richard (African-American) was in a cab headed back to his home in Long Beach, after being gone six weeks. Donny was barefoot, and had dried blood on his arms and head. He was in front of the check-cashing place on Hollywood at McCadden, at about 6:30 a.m. I asked if he was okay, and was there anyone I could call to arrange him getting home to. He told me he was from Chicago. His family was there. Every Monday and every Friday morning they wired him $250. He loved living on the street, being free of rules, even if it meant getting beaten up every so often and waking up in strange places. He wouldn’t have it any other way. Valerie lived in her car behind the McDonalds on Western near where I’d found Richard. One day we transported her to a senior citizen’s service center near our station. She met with a caseworker to arrange housing. I drove her back to her car. She swore up and down I’d never see her again, living in her car. She was back a week later. Too many rules. She’d rather be on her own. Dawn from Mississippi had left her double-wide after becoming enamored with Star Trek – The Next Generation’s Capt. Jean Luc Picard (played by Patrick Stewart). Picard may have been conversing with other characters on the screen, but his subliminal messages were aimed at Dawn. She heard him say that she needed to come to Hollywood and await his arrival. She parked herself in one of the southern exposed alcoves on Melrose, near Gower. She did not eat. She did not drink. She never left to make use of any indoor bathroom. She did not protect herself from the sun. She just waited for Capt. Picard. Almost dehydrated and very sunburned with blisters, I took her in to have her evaluated by LAPD the Mental Evaluation Unit. Determining that she was “no danger to herself or others” I was told she was free to go. I was amazed and drove her back right to where I’d found her. Then I read an article about a new L.A. County task force making on-scene responses to incidents with the mentally ill. I called them after finishing my reading. They were very interested in her. Not only was Dawn gone within 24 hours. Her story was in the Los Angeles Times touted as the reason this new task force existed. I heard the LAPD detective who told me to take her back was embarrassed by reading the story in the paper, to the point of altering his notes in case his bosses found out what had happened. Mark from Arkansas – after promoting to sergeant and being entrusted with the (then) newly issued cell phones, I met Mark in an alley near USC. His accent betrayed any pretense of being from anywhere other than a southern state. I ask him about his presence on the street, offering to mail & receive a letter for him, or even allowing him to use the cell phone to call family. He thanked me, but declined as he stated he had, “no one to call.” Sakke the Finnish Postman was enjoying his winter vacation in L.A.’s Echo Park, where he eschewed showering, shaving, sleeping indoors and solid foods. He really preferred to drink all day and night with other homeless park-dwellers. It seems that Sakke always wintered in Los Angeles, overstaying any visa. In the spring, upon figuring out that Helsinki was probably thawing out, he would surrender himself to US immigration authorities for voluntary deportation, so he could get back to work. His superiors HAD to hold his job for him. Thinking about it, Finland’s winters were probably as rough for postal workers as they were for invading Soviets and Germans. I’m sure they’d have rather invaded Southern California, as well. Sakke always returned to deliver mail, washed, shaved and rested, saving money for his next plane ticket to L.A. I wonder if he even bothered to pack for these journeys. So, folks, when we speak of homelessness we have to expand our presumptions about just who they are and why they are where they are. If society is diverse in regards to colors, genders, creeds, sexual orientations and national origins then the reasons for homelessness can be just as diverse. Just as there are victims, there are volunteers. People who have decided that their course is outdoors and away from rules imposed by others. We really could build shelters and serve three meals a day, give them cable TV, and let them choose from a dessert tray, even. Yet, someone will stay on the street for the freedom from the norm, and “other’s rules”, that it offers.

No one deserves homelessness.  No one. Ever. Sadly, too many think they do, though.  And without much distinction of the different reasons for homelessness. I have been close to all the reasons. 1.  I had a cousin who was abused by his father his entire childhood.  His mother was too.  She divorced the asshole, but Johnny never recovered.  He never felt comfortable in any place for too long, was happier wandering the streets, and could be found flopping at any one of a number of homeless shelters in the city.  My Grandmother would bring him home and clean him up for the holidays, but he always went back.  He deserved better than the life he lived.  With a little therapy, he might have done better.  He passed away on the street a few years back, and none of us found out until some of the volunteers he knew dropped off his few belongings.   2.  Some friends in Virginia had bought a very nice home and had resided in it for several years.  The family was having bouts of a mysterious illness, until they discovered a black mold growing in much of the interior walls.  They had to move out, but didn't have enough to rent a place, so they depended on the generosity of friends and lived in a tent in a series of backyards.  The insurance claim was denied after multiple attempts.  This began over a decade ago, and last I heard, they were still not able to live in the house. 3.  The father of another family we were friends with about 15 years ago lost his job.  He was a veteran, as was his wife, but wasn't able to find any viable work.  His wife was unable to work, having had what was believed to be nerve damage from a rough childbirth, but it turned out to be multiple sclerosis  They ended up out on the street, having lost a nice house.  After about a year, he finally got a job, which paid enough for them to rent a house and get a used car.  She began classes to become  a lawyer.  However, he began having intense migraines and ended up losing his job again after a year.  They eked out a living for another few years in odd jobs and working some for their church, but after he committed suicide, the younger children ended up with one of the older siblings, and the wife, now bedridden, ended up with us for a short time until she found a more permanent placement. What many people fail to realize is that homelessness is not the fault fo the person who has no home.  To say they deserve it says much for the person saying it.  I hear so called Christians of all walks make this statement, thinking that anyone can better their lot in life if they just work harder.  This is rarely the case.  These are people most in need of help.  Not necessarily monetary or even public services.  Sometimes, a reference for a job application, sometimes just a few nights under a friendly roof. Part of the problem with homelessness is that, to get anywhere in the world, you need a permanent address.  To get a job, you need an address.  To get assistance, you need an address.   There is no shortage of people willing to create shelters and temporary housing for the homeless, but many neighborhoods believe having one in their midst will create more crime and public annoyances.  In some cases this might be true, but not always.  Many shelters, aware of these concerns, are very careful to prevent these problems. This means the rules to live in these places are usually draconian, with eviction as the most common result of infractions, which also prevents any future ability to utilize other shelters. The shelters that do get approved are usually in rundown areas or far out from the places where jobs and services can be found.  Transportation then becomes an issue. Many of those I know personally without a home are out of work due to the economy, or that their skills are obsolete, or they were let go because a younger, cheaper replacement had been found.  Getting another job after a certain age is difficult at best, and after being out of work for too long means you are less attractive since your skills are "rusty".

I don't think anyone deserves to be homeless. But, I do believe a good number of them did it to themselves. Homeless people don't come in just one flavor. There are, believe it or not, people who choose it over the alternative. There are people who are homeless but have shelter; such as living in a vehicle. There are homeless that are not chronically homeless, but are in temporary period because of a fountian of reasons. There are people wirh deug addictions and behavioral and emotional health problems. And these are the broad categories. You can break it down further. None of these people deserve to be homeless, but many of them set themselves up for failure. I did an outreach event in Colorado Springs with VFW to get homeless Veterans into shelters. It seemed like about every fifth person claimed to be a Veteran. In two days of talking over 100 people, most of them claiming to be Vets, we came across about 10 that were eligible for any assistance. We found a bunch of people who claimed to have joined, but never made it out of basic training. We found a few with other than honorable or dishonorable duscharges, thus disqualifying them from benefits. Our ten legit guys all turned down the offer of living in a home. We helped them max out their benefits, make sure they had proper ID cards and information on where they could go if they changed their minds or needed help and a number of other things. But, they prefered the streets. No rules. No responsibilities. We brought these horses to water, they wanted alcohol instead. Alon the way, we came across a bunch of other homeless people. We would hand out little care packages, compile data and give them information on charitable and government programs and organizations they could use. What surprised me among many of these people was how many were kind of new to being homeless. And theu were clueless about how to get help. They ew they could get a meal every day at Acacia Park in the middle of town. They new were the shelters were. But that was about it. They didn't talk to the other homeless folks because they were scared. They didn't talk to the social workers at the shelters because theu didn't think they could help. They didn't talk to the ecclesiastical people because they weren't church goers. They avoided the police because they didn't want to get in trouble. These people were usually in a vehicle. They had recently lost a job or acquired too much debt to pay their bills. At the time, the legalization of pot had drawn a lot of prospectors who wanted to get into the pot business because they were very ignorant of what they were getting into. It never occurred to them that being a pot head wasn't what the new industry was looking for. So now they're stuck in Colorado with no job and no family. None of these people deserve to be homeless. But helping them requires a tailor made solution and some effort on their part.

How does one deserve to be homeless? What an odd concept! If you are asking if they made poor decisions that led them to the situation? Many probably did. Most of us do every day. Not all, but many. Most of us live paycheck to paycheck, not planning for future problems. That was the one lesson I got out of being homeless…to plan for a negative event that may destroy my normalcy. We live like we can afford to buy needless things and seem shocked when we learn we really never needed those things at all because we are a society of consumerism. Most of the people that I stayed in winter shelters with, seemed as if they had finally given up on any decent life. They had accepted their failures and even clothed themselves in failure now. There were those occasional ill-planned people who were fired or laid off from work, who had no savings and ended up on the streets. There were also several people who had terminal illnesses and no ability to care for themselves and no income to support themselves. I always hated that the shelters didn’t seem to place them first as to me, they seemed the neediest. There were couples with children, where dad couldn’t seem to get off his butt and seek a job because he would rather have government help and take his kids to the movies every day, or hang out at the park. Those used to nauseate me, because they hung out in groups being lazy and had no medical or psychological diagnoses that justified giving up. There were the usual hookers and drug addicts. But there were also actors and kids who didn’t want to go home because they loved partying in the streets and called themselves neo-hobos. I don’t feel anyone deserves to be homeless though. I think with all of the empty buildings in any city, there is a solution to where the buildings could house many of the homeless and with counseling, they could get their confidence back. Even through all the hateful and nasty homeless people I was forced to deal with…people who threatened to fight me for simply looking at them, or people in electric wheelchairs that threatened to run me over because they were simply angry and mean, or even the meth heads that slept beside me in their bunk, staring at me and playing with themselves, I don’t think these people deserve homelessness. Some deserve a swift kick in the ass for being disgusting, but they all deserve to have a place to live, even if it is shared with others.

I am going to voice a contrary opinion. They probably do deserve it. Assuming that what we “deserve” is based on the decisions we make. Especially in the USA, people who are homeless are usually in that position because they made some really terrible life decisions. People in many poor countries would kill for the opportunities afforded even to the most disadvantaged in the USA, and homeless folks are people who have largely squandered those opportunities. However, I think that it is backwards, counter-productive, and wicked to make moral decisions based on what people “deserve”. I have much more than what I deserve. As do most people, especially in my country. Those who obsess over getting what they “deserve” probably would not like what they deserve were they to actually receive it. If I were to get what I truly deserve, I fear that I just might be the one living under the bridge. We should not be seeking to mete out what everyone “deserves”. Not only are we not good judges of that, but if we really were to apply that standard universally, it would backfire significantly on us. When it comes to the homeless, we should not look at what they deserve. Instead, we should look at their potential. What can they become? What small investment can get them moving in that direction? Of course, by “investment”, I do not necessarily mean cash. Actually, in most cases, cash would not help at all. But they do need help, and we, acknowledging their worth, should give them that. Do we deserve to be saved from the undesirable consequences of our own poor decisions? Probably not. But we all seek that very thing, do we not?

No one "deserves" to be "homeless." It is simply a state of being that a relatively few people in any overall populace find themselves in at various stages of their lives. I do have to disagree with Murray Godfrey; it couldn't happen to most people. Most people have a support network who they can fall back upon or they realize that they may have to change something about themselves to find shelter. The homeless people with whom I worked shared many commonalities, although the primary reason for their being homeless differed: They had damaged or non-existent ties to their families - Many people wouldn't be homeless if they had a strong family bond. Unfortunately, most of the homeless people I had met, had abused or misused their families to the point where staying with them (even briefly) was not an option.They frequently engaged in magical thinking - I have seen people take money which could have enabled them to find shelter and gamble it away. Or give to a charity when they desperately needed it for themselves. These people seemed to believe that they would somehow either "win" enough money to take care of their needs. Or that their charitable gifts would be rewarded by some higher power.They had problems with authority - The phrase " I don't like people telling me what to do" is mantra to many homeless people. While most of us chafe under the authority of another, few of us will allow that dislike to translate into losing a place to stay or employment. Unfortunately many people who are homeless, will allow their difficulties with authority to override their common sense and the needs of their families and they find that they are homeless as a result.They are often not patient - While most of us hate to wait, we all realize that it is another of life's unpleasant realities. Many homeless people (whether through mental or emotional illness, substance abuse or immaturity) take this to extremes. I have seen people leave lines to get into shelters for the night because (they said) they were sick of waiting. I have seen people leaving busy benefits offices where they were going to receive preciously needed funds, because they had to wait for them. I have witnessed people quit temp jobs because they didn't want to work overtime and wait until they got off to do what they wanted to do. A lack of patience often exacerbates homelessness.They could not plan - They literally would mistake ideas for detailed plans and then be surprised when those ideas were not sufficient enough to obtain them what they needed. Instead of sitting down (as they had plenty of time) and working out a plan (or plans) to get their lives back on track (if they ever were) they would bounce from one idea to the next, hoping that "this one" would be the one that would work. They were almost always wrong; and for myriad reasons, they were never able to see why this was the case.They failed to learn from their mistakes - Consistently failing to learn from one's mistakes is a key component to continued homelessness. If you can't reflect upon how your current situation resembles other situations which did not work, you will again make the same or similar mistakes that you already have. If you have a close-knit family, substantial savings and a good job, you can usually weather hard times. If you do not, you may find that homelessness is in your future.The homeless situation in America today was caused by a perfect storm of events,including: The closure of many state run mental institutions and the belief that the mentally ill could self-medicate effectivelyThe collapse of America's manufacturing base as a source of jobs for marginal or low-skill employeesThe collapse of the American family structure and the belief that "leaving home" despite financial insecurity was what all high school aged children needed to do.The belief by many that they didn't need to get married and that pair-bonding was somehow "archaic"The "Baby Boom" after WWII increasing the population.The end of vagrancy laws in many communities.The removal of shaming factors which prevented many from becoming substance abuse addicts or allowed that addiction to surmount their need to remain employed.The election of successive governments (at all levels) which were then not required resolve to effectively end the burgeoning homeless problem.No one should be homeless.Homelessness occurs when other issues are not addressed.

In essence, this question is asking whether or not we think human beings should be held accountable for the condition of their lives. My short answer: Yes. Being homeless is not a permanent, immutable condition, especially in the USA. Consider that in ancient Hawaii, we had a caste system and no land ownership. The lowest caste (kaua) were branded, treated as slaves, and considered “untouchable”. In comparison, the homeless in America live in a relative lap of luxury as they have the entire welfare system at their disposal. As a Christian nation, we are extremely compassionate - sometimes to a fault. Many of the homeless in Hawaii are on drugs or drunk, committing crimes, and urinating/defecating on the beaches. I asked a Japanese friend who lives here why we have so many homeless. Her answer: “Because you allow it.” Even if you disagree, think of it this way: Do housed people deserve to be housed? Do working people deserve to be working? Do healthy people deserve to be healthy? It sounds absurd, because it is. A housed person who pays their mortgage on time deserves to live there. A working person who does their job continues to work. A healthy person who takes care of themselves will be healthy. This is a universal law of cause and effect, whether we like it or not. The notion that anyone deserves anything is based on religious and political ideas of social norms. It is based on a puritanical notion that we only get what we work for. It is based on the idea that there is justice in the world and that we can know what is just and what isn't.  These are all social fictions. Myths. There is no there to these ideas. Rather, there is no objectivity to these ideas, although people act as if the notion that we deserve things is objective, when, in fact, it is purely subjective, or it is a conglomeration of many different individuals' points of view.  If there is no objective justice, then no one can deserve anything. We can have opinions about whether we approve or disapprove of someone's behavior, but to say that opinion translates into objective deserving is the height of self-righteousness. It is also, I would argue, the height of inhumanity. I don't want to live in a world where people deserve anything. We shouldn't have to earn the approval of others to do anything. We shouldn't have to decide, in our own minds, whether we are deserving before we allow ourselves to live. I've heard people say that half of the homeless are mentally ill. I've heard others say it's three-quarters. Some people are incapable of making a home for themselves. Some people don't want to. There have been times in my life, when I felt I did not deserve a wife, children, home, job or anything. I was hellbent on making them all go away because I knew I deserved nothing. Less than nothing. I deserved, in fact, to die. I am only alive because I have learned that deserving is a red herring. It is irrelevant. There is no deserving. Believing that there is deserving is a sign of mental illness for me, and I suspect it is the same for most people. Except most people can ask if they are deserving and answer yes. I cannot. Since I cannot, I dare not ask the question. For that way lies death. The fact is that I deserve to die. Now. That's what my brain tells me whenever I ask the question. That's why I cannot dare to ask the question. I don't want to die. Since I cannot ask the question of myself, I also cannot ask it of anyone else.  What I have found is that I prefer compassion. I don't deserve compassion. Neither does anyone else. But I do prefer it. Life is happier when I am compassionate and when others are compassionate. Things work better.  So let's help the homeless. Individually or as a society. It's easier when professionals do it. Lets help them get into homes and get medications and get jobs. I guarantee you that we will all be better off if we do this. They will be more productive, on average. So will everyone else. When you aren't mentally ill, you can do more things.  When I say productive, I don't mean productive as society might think of it. I just mean able to take on tasks and do more of them. It might be as simple as making a cup of coffee. Or getting out of bed.  The homeless don't deserve to be homeless. Neither do they deserve to have homes. They, like everyone else. don't deserve anything.  However, if we practice compassion, we and everyone else, including the homeless will be better off. We don't have to be compassionate. We don't deserve compassion. But I prefer it, and I hope enough other people do, too.

In some ways, yes. I’m always interested in hearing people’s stories about how they are homeless, because that’s when I start asking questions. One guy said he was working as a contractor building homes. He said he’s apartment burnt down, and he didn’t have insurance, so he lost all his stuff, and started living in public housing. Then he didn’t want to get a job, because if he got a job, then he’d lose the public housing. This was played in class at college. That’s when the teacher said “see it can happen to anyone”. Really? Where was his family? Where was her family? Why didn’t they live with the family until he could earn a few dollars to buy new tools? Why didn’t he get a job anyway? Yes he would have lost the apartment, but if he never gets a job, he’ll be stuck there until he dies. Wouldn’t it be better to lose the apartment, rent a tiny studio until he earns money, buy tools, and goes back to building homes? Where were their friends? Where was their church? Why didn’t they have friends and a church family that could help? Where was the insurance? Contractors building homes are not cheap. He should have had insurance. Why didn’t he have money saved? On and on, the list goes. There was another story I heard over the BBC. This guy lost his job, and just went to live in the airport. He lived there for couple of years. Finally he got caught by the police, and kicked out. He immediately asked someone for help, and they put him up until he got a job, and got his own apartment. So why was he homeless for years, when he could have ask them for help at the very start? Pride. He didn’t want to have to ask someone for help. So instead he remained homeless for years. And I could get into a laundry list of other questions as to why he was homeless. Of course the brutal truth is that, at least here in America, could be different elsewhere, most homeless are … NOT homeless. We had a reporter follow a guy, and we walked a few blocks, got into a late-model car, and drove away. There are some people who end up homeless by circumstance, but few of those people stay there. The people that are consistently homeless for periods of time, often there is a reason. Something they did that made them un-employable, or something they refuse to do, like an honest days work.

"Deserve" To merit, to be worthy of, to qualify for reward, assistance or punishment because of actions, qualities or situation. This question - do homeless people deserve to be homeless? - assumes that homelessness is a punishment for a negative quality or behavior. So, what deeds would merit this punishment: lack of comfort, warmth, sound sleep, shelter from rain and snow? If we examine homeless people, we find a predictable set of issues that contribute to their situation: alcoholism, drug addiction, mental illness, limited intellectual ability, childlike incompetence, post-traumatic stress syndrome and/or catastrophic financial events. To simplify, you could just say mental illness. So, illness puts these people at a level of function below the minimum standards of our societies, to enjoy shelter? If we lived in a more primitive, tribal society, the same people would be able to fashion some kind of shelter for themselves, but modern society has a minimum financial threshold they cannot achieve. They cannot pay the vig to the middlemen that control housing here, that did not exist in the wild. Does the punishment produce any results? Does it help them to desire a home sufficiently to try harder? Does it improve their chances of becoming employed? Of course not. Homelessness is a cruel punishment we assign to the incompetent. It is a convenient, self-serving lie that their suffering is deserved, like saying a rape victim was dressed in an immodest way and so deserved assault, for insulting our morality. It makes us feel better about ourselves, to compare our relative success with hapless, unable people; like prize fighting the elderly, it makes us feel strong. But, do you know who else is incompetent to work, to earn and to pay? Innocent children. Though they may be intelligent, mentally stable, industrious and moral, they can and are made homeless. How do they deserve to be punished? How do you think homelessness changes a child?

No. As a human being, I have empathy and compassion and do not believe anyone “deserves” the misfortune of having no home. As a Social Worker and manager of a specialist homelessness services program, I can do a deeper dive into the common experience of this cohort. The majority of people experiencing homelessness have also experienced some kind of trauma prior to their first homeless episode. The program I manage has been well researched. In that program over 75% of people had their first episode of homelessness (of any kind) before they were 18. 50% had an episode of rough sleeping before they were 18. That speaks to a pattern of instability so early in life that they were not able to develop the capacity to manage life’s basic tasks independently. This results in people developing negative coping skills such a drug use. Additionally, a large proportion also have diagnosed mental health conditions. Couple this with the fact that there is little to no affordable housing and few long term support options make it extremely difficult to make significant change. I’ve heard all the arguments about people choosing to experience homelessness, not wanting to work, etc. I can understand why people may think that but the reality is that the people I work with are so beat down that they have given up trying. The road back is too hard. They have little to no family support. I am well aware that there are outliers and people with individual different experiences, but in my career they have been the exception not the rule. No one deserves to not have a place to live. It is a travesty in this day and age.

It seems to me that in the 21st century this question should no longer be pondered. But since it is, I will offer my opinion. No one but no one deserves to live in the elements without access to the basic needs of food, sanitary conditions, and a safe, warm place to sleep. No one. You’d be surprised by the situations that can put people in this situation. Before losing housing, people often lead normal lives. Generally, a life situation such as an illness, a job loss, drug dependency can prevent a person from being able to keep up with the financial responsibilities of keeping traditional housing. These are situations where people have often lost the ability to do for themselves in some capacity and need assistance, not judgment. Where the idea of judging people when they are in the most need started is unclear, but it has caused devastation to many innocent lives. It is a vicious cycle and it is easy to become caught in its grasp. A stressful situation may lead to drug use which people often use to cope. Drugs can become addicting making one ineligible for services. Children who were born to parents who wouldn’t or couldn't care for them are literally put outdoors when they reach adulthood if they weren’t fortunate enough to get adopted during their youth. There are so many scenarios that can cause a person to become homeless, none of which lead me to believe they deserve to live in that manner. Under the facade of a Christian, god-fearing nation, there are people who based on life circumstances often beyond their control will be misunderstood and may never have access to a normal life. Somehow we have come to believe that people experiencing homelessness are a different breed of human not realizing that horrific circumstances may have separated us from the rest of society. Whether those circumstances are a culmination of childhood trauma or an adult crisis matters little. What does matter is that homelessness is a horrible social It is and has always been a crisis. The sad fact that we live in a world that has normalized it by no means that anyone should be subjected to it.

No.  Most of the homeless people I've talked to were at one time "normal" people.  Something happened in their lives that they couldn't handle.  Many of them are borderline or have full-fledged mental illnesses that may have contributed to the crisis or their inability to adapt.  Addiction is often involved too, either before, during, or after homelessness. What's so scary about it is that it could really happen to anyone.  The sense that I get is, once you're on the street for a few weeks to a few months, you start to lose touch with your humanity and reality as you knew it.  People stop treating you the same way.  They want to avoid you, not acknowledge you, or both.  That's hard to deal with.  If you're not crazy before that, it will make you crazy after a few months.  Not many of us could handle it. This is why homeless rehabilitation involves multiple steps of relearning how to live and engage with society, and it is very difficult. I remember how my thinking on homeless people changed.  I was working fast food as a 19-yr old kid.  A homeless guy walked in, bought a couple items from the 99 cent menu with money he had been given.  Then, he asked for a job application.  The manager gave one to him, the man filled it out and turned it back in to us, then left.  The manager waited a minute, then threw it into the trash.  "That guy would scare customers away," the manager said.   With that statement he meant much more - 1) a homeless man is not worthy of even a fast food job.2) He's frightening to "normal" people - even the kind of folks that frequent fast food.  Thus not normal himself. That's why I hate it when people say they just "need to get jobs."  No one will give them one.  That's a big part of poverty that people overlook- the poorer you look, the more prejudice against you.

But the majority of the homeless got there because of a cycle of social injustice that is nearly impossible to escape. And the vast majority of people simply have no concept of the nearly insurmountable array of challenges that perpetuate this life. Who in the US deserves to face the indescribable poverty that leads to homelessness in one of the wealthiest nations on the planet.

I held homelessness over my head as a notice that I deserved being homeless as a penance for judging others for their shortcomings. But isn’t thinking you are ‘supposed to be homeless’ counterintuitive to logical thinking? Perhaps. Perhaps not. When one has a belief in a superior being, and one believes in karma, one is willing to believe that they are where they belong until whatever lesson is learned that was supposed to be learned. That’s why I don’t judge the homeless anymore - I have always held a belief very similar to what I just described. Is it a sanity issue? No. A belief problem? There are already many answers to this question, and many of them are quite good, such as Glenn R. Anderson’s answer. Yet, I thought I could say a few words as well. :) I don’t think that desert has to be equated here. Why does one want to know if someone deserves to be in homelessness? What is the deep reason for that? One possibility is that it is a matter of finding an excuse to dehumanize and not care about people who struggle on the streets. I think that desert and merit may apply very well to some things, such as when you are competing for a promotion or an entry into a university. Yet, I don’t think that deciding to what extent a person brought misery onto himself does anything useful for anyone. Yes, people must be accountable for their decisions, especially when they harm others, so that they can learn and develop and stop harming others, but they must always be given the opportunity to get up on their feet again - everyone has a value as a living and a human being. The natural and desirable state of a human being in most societies is not a state where he/she lives on the streets. So, in an attempt to answer the question directly, I would say that nobody deserves to be homeless. Homelessness is not something a homeless person does to other people and that harms them. Homelessness is something that society allows to happen - and sometimes even makes happen (think of cases in which a person stops being able to pay a mortgage and is forced to the streets or in which a teenager is kicked out of home for any arbitrary reason). Homelessness is not an unethical act, it is not even an act in the traditional sense of an act. Secondly, in reality there are so many factors that we do not control in our lives and that the illusion of being captains in full control of our ships (lives) does not let us see, that sometimes things get really bad and we don’t even see a storm coming, or are frankly unprepared to face it. This is why people in homelessness have different backgrounds and different reasons to be in such a situation, although there can be some common factors such as mental disease, ilness or addiction. The Canadian Observatory on Homelessness is quite elucidative: “Individuals and families who experience homelessness may not share much in common with each other, aside from the fact that they are extremely vulnerable, and lack adequate housing and income and the necessary supports to ensure they stay housed. The causes of homelessness reflect an intricate interplay between structural factors, systems failures and individual circumstances. Homelessness is usually the result of the cumulative impact of a number of factors, rather than a single cause.” Most of us have safety nets that wouldn’t allow us to become homeless, such as reliable families, friends or neighbours, savings, an ensurance (in some countries), a certain amount of wealth that can be sold in a case of an emergency and even good social services to help us get by in case of unemployment or disease. But, unfortunately, many people don’t have most or any of these safety nets - or they fail. Then, all that is needed is the perfect storm that can easily sink an already frail ship. In one sentence we can sum it up as “The causes and factors contributing to homelessness are too complex to allow us to fairly blame people who are in homelessness for the suffering they are going through.”. You will agree with me that nobody in their sane mind would prefer to live on the streets unless for some kind of a social experiment. We are psychologically, socially and biologically conditioned to seek the comfort and the safety of a house. If a sane person ends up on the street, it is because he/she couldn’t find a way to avoid it - and how can he/she be blamed for not having achieved what is in his/her best interest? And if a person is insane and is on the streets, how can he/she be blamed either if she/he is not able to make sound judgements and act accordingly?

Matthew Meadows wrote : “When I see a homeless person I see myself. Half of the country can't handle a $500 emergency. They're one paycheck away from eviction. God forbid they suffer from mental illness or chemical dependency, make a mistake at work or commit a minor crime. Most shelters only accept "clean" patients so they're faced with agonizing & potentially fatal withdrawal or trying to survive alone in freezing weather. I'm of the opinion that there is no such thing as "deserving" anything. What happens happens. Some of it is under your control, some of it is not. "Deserving" is a way for people to rationalize and justify the past, not a forward-looking philosophy.  "Oh, he probably deserved it" - what people say when they don't want to expend the energy to consider someone's humanity. "I deserve better!" - what people say to try to make their own self-interest into a greater cause. Why not just say "I want better!" or "I need better!" ? "The (insert demographic you are pandering to) people DESERVE (insert thing they don't have)" - what politicians say to mobilize political capital.  In all these examples, deserving is at best an intellectually lazy way of approximating a deeper meaning, and at worst a way to play on people's emotions or dehumanize someone.  No one deserves anything. The end.

They can’t hold down a job, so they can’t move out of their parent’s home. Eventually, their family’s can no longer tolerate them, so they turn them out into the street, hoping that they will be “scared straight.” That strategy rarely works. On the street, alcohol and drug abusers find many “birds of a feather,” and for a long time they flock together. Yet, precisely because of their incessant alcohol and drug abuse, they eventually break up. Now we have single strays — the average type of homeless person. They won’t listen to the Preacher — but they will take the Free Soup. Charity is all we know how to do for them. Without a physical address, our Government has no way to contact them. They become statistics. Do they “deserve” homelessness? That’s debatable — but we must each ask ourselves how we propose to care for an alcohol or drug abuser. There are surely other types of homeless people — but they typically don’t stay homeless for long — they soon reach out for Government or Church help to get back on their feet.
